maml:description.maml:para:
Causes the modified security descriptor to be saved. By default, when a security descriptor object is provided as input to the InputObject parameter, the in memory security descriptor is changed, and a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor saves the changes. Using the Apply switch causes the change to be made without a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor.
If a non security descriptor object is provided as input and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
When the -Apply switch is used, or when a non-security descriptor object is passed as input, this switch parameter suppresses any prompts about saving the changes to the security descriptor.

A securable object whose ACL will be changed. This can either be an instance of an object, e.g., output from Get-CimInstance, Get-ChildItem, Get-Item, etc, or a string pointing to the location of the securable object. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module for more information.
.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
Shows what would happen if the function were to make changes. No changes are made when this switch is used.
Prompts you for confirmation before making any changes.

If a non security descriptor object is provided as input and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
When the -Apply switch is used, or when a non-security descriptor object is passed as input, this switch parameter suppresses any prompts about saving the changes to the security descriptor.

.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.

This cmdlet takes several types of objects as input, including objects output from Get-Item, Get-ChildItem, Get-WmiObject, Get-CimInstance, Get-Acl, and simple strings.
The command only writes output if the PassThru parameter was provided.
Disables inheritance for discretionary and system ACLs on security descriptors.
The Disable-AclInheiritance command disabled inheritance for both discretionary and system ACLs (DACLs and SACLs).

If it is called without the DiscretionaryAcl and SystemAcl switches (aliased as Access and Audit, respectively), the command will behave as if the DiscretionaryAcl switch was provided, and the DACL inheritance will be disabled.
Please see the about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module help for a description of when a modified security descriptor is automatically saved.
This command does the opposite of the Enable-PacAclInheritance command.

Converts any inherited ACEs to explicitly defined entries before disabling inheritance. If this switch isn't provided, a prompt is displayed asking for the expected behavior (unless the Force switch is provided).
By default, any inherited ACEs are removed when the inheritance is disabled.
Causes inheritance to be changed for the discretionary ACL (DACL), or the ACL that deals with who or what is granted or denied permissions over the object.
This switch can be used along with the SystemAcl switch. If neither switch is provided, the function behaves as if this was the only one of the two switches provided.
Causes inheritance to be changed for the system ACL (SACL), or the ACL that deals with what types of access to the object is audited.
This switch can be used along with the DiscretionaryAcl switch. If neither switch is provided, the function behaves as if the DiscretionaryAcl switch was the only one of the two switches provided.

If a non security descriptor object is provided as input and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
When the -Apply switch is used, or when a non-security descriptor object is passed as input, this switch parameter suppresses any prompts about saving the changes to the security descriptor.

Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.

By default, any inherited ACEs are removed when the inheritance is disabled.

Enables inheritance for discretionary and system ACLs on security descriptors.
The Enable-PacAclInheritance command enables inheritance for both discretionary (access) and system (auditing) access control lists (ACLs).

If it is called without the DiscretionaryAcl and SystemAcl switches (aliased as Access and Audit, respectively), the command will behave as if the DiscretionaryAcl switch was provided, and the DACL inheritance will be enabled.
Please see the about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module help for a description of when a modified security descriptor is automatically saved.
This command does the opposite of the Disable-PacAclInheritance command.
Causes inheritance to be changed for the discretionary ACL (DACL), or the ACL that deals with who or what is granted or denied permissions over the object.
This switch can be used along with the SystemAcl switch. If neither switch is provided, the function behaves as if this was the only one of the two switches provided.

This cmdlet takes several types of objects as input, including objects output from Get-Item, Get-ChildItem, Get-WmiObject, Get-CimInstance, Get-Acl, and simple strings.
If the SeSecurityPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch causes the PAC cmdlet to get a security descriptor that includes the System ACL (SACL; the list that includes audit entries).

By default, the Owner, Group, and Discretionary ACL (DACL; the list that controls who's granted/denied access) are retrieved for the object specified by InputObject. This switch will cause the SACL to also be retrieved.
This is a shortcut for providing a PacSDOption that uses the GetSacl switch. See the help for New-PacSDOption for more information.

A securable object whose security descriptor will be obtained. This can either be an instance of an object, e.g., output from Get-CimInstance, Get-ChildItem, Get-Item, etc, or a string pointing to the location of the securable object. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module for more information.
.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
If the SeSecurityPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch causes the PAC cmdlet to get a security descriptor that includes the System ACL (SACL; the list that includes audit entries).

By default, the Owner, Group, and Discretionary ACL (DACL; the list that controls who's granted/denied access) are retrieved for the object specified by InputObject. This switch will cause the SACL to also be retrieved.
This is a shortcut for providing a PacSDOption that uses the GetSacl switch. See the help for New-PacSDOption for more information.

A securable object whose security descriptor will be obtained. This can either be an instance of an object, e.g., output from Get-CimInstance, Get-ChildItem, Get-Item, etc, or a string pointing to the location of the securable object. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module for more information.
.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
This cmdlet takes several types of objects as input, including objects output from Get-Item, Get-ChildItem, Get-WmiObject, Get-CimInstance, Get-Acl, and simple strings.
Creates an object that can be passed to the AccessMask parameter of PowerShell Access Control module commands.

The New-PacAccessMask command provides a way to create valid AccessMask objects that can be used for the AccessMask parameter of other PowerShell Access Control commands, including Add-PacAccessControlEntry, Remove-PacAccessControlEntry, New-PacAccessControlEntry, and Get-PacAccessControlEntry.

Those commands take any object that can be converted into a numeric value. You usually wouldn't use a numeric AccessMask directly, though, because it's hard to understand the resulting permissions. For that reason, enmerations such as FileSystemRights and RegistryRights are usually used. They provide a string view that is backed by a numeric value.

New-PacAccessMask provides a shortcut to create enumerations for different types of securable objects, including files, folders, registry keys, printers, WMI namespaces, Active Directory objects, shares, services, and processes.
For example, this: PS> New-PacAccessControlEntry -Principal Users -AccessMask ([PowerShellAccessControl.ServiceAccessRights] "Start, Stop")
Can become this: PS> New-PacAccessControlEntry -Principal Users -AccessMask (New-PacAccessMask -ServiceRights Start, Stop)
Specifies an access mask using a filesystem-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a registry-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using an Active Directory-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a share-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a printer-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a WMI namespace-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a service-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a process-specific enumeration.
Specifies a numeric access mask. Instead of using this parameter with New-AccessMask, though, you could simply pass a numeric value to one of the PAC modification cmdlets.
Specifies an access mask using a filesystem-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a registry-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using an Active Directory-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a share-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a printer-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a WMI namespace-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a service-specific enumeration.
Specifies an access mask using a process-specific enumeration.
Specifies a numeric access mask. Instead of using this parameter with New-AccessMask, though, you could simply pass a numeric value to one of the PAC modification cmdlets.

dev:type.maml:name: This command does not take pipeline input.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will create an access ACE that grants 'Users' ReadAndExecute and CreateDirectories file system rights that applies to a Folder, SubFolders, and Files (the ACE wouldn't necessarily have to be used with a folder; a file would still work)

That's not the best example, though, since New-PacAccesControlEntry has a parameter just for FolderRights. This command would produce an identical ACE as the previous one: PS> New-PacAccessControlEntry -Principal Users -FolderRights ReadAndExecute, CreateDirectories

One last example of a command that would produce an identical ACE: PS> New-PacAccessControlEntry -Principal Users -AccessMask ([System.Security.AccessControl.FileSystemRights] "ReadAndExecute, CreateDirectories")

AccessControlType : Allow Principal : BUILTIN\Users Rights : CreateDirectories/AppendData, ReadAndExecute AppliesTo : Object, ChildContainers, ChildObjects IdentityReference : S-1-5-32-545 IsInherited : False InheritanceFlags : ContainerInherit, ObjectInherit PropagationFlags : None

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS> New-PacAccessControlEntry -AceType Deny -Principal Users -AccessMask (New-PacAccessMask -ServiceRights Start, Stop)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will create an access ACE that denies 'Users' the ability to Start and Stop a service. It produces identical output as this one:
AccessControlType : Deny Principal : BUILTIN\Users Rights : Start, Stop AppliesTo : Object IdentityReference : S-1-5-32-545 IsInherited : False InheritanceFlags : None PropagationFlags : None

This will create an access ACE that grants 'Users' whatever rights a numeric access mask of 1 means (the meaning depends on the type of the object that the ACE will be assigned to). Using New-PacAccessMask isn't necessary in this example, though, because the following command would work exactly the same:
AccessControlType : Allow Principal : BUILTIN\Users Rights : Unknown (1) AppliesTo : Object IdentityReference : S-1-5-32-545 IsInherited : False InheritanceFlags : None PropagationFlags : None

maml:description.maml:para: Creates and object that contains advanced options for a PowerShell Access Control Module command.

The New-PacSdOption cmdlet creates an object that contains advanced options for a PAC (PowerShell Access Control) module command. You can use the object as the value of the PacSDOption parameter of other PAC cmdlets, such as Get-PacSecurityDescriptor, Set-PacSecurityDescriptor, Get-PacAccessControlEntry, Add-PacAccessControlEntry, Remove-PacAccessControlEntry, Disable-PacAclInheritance, Enable-PacAclInheritance, and Set-PacOwner.
Without parameters, New-PacSdOption creates an object that contains the default values for all of the options.

Note that several of these advanced options are ignored if the InputObject on the cmdlet with the PacSDOption parameter is a string. Also, some options are only used if the string is for a certain provider. For example, File and Directory are only used for string paths for the filesystem. BypassAclCheck, however, can be used for any InputObject, as long as it is for a filesystem or registry object. See the parameter details for more information.
When the InputObject parameter of a PAC cmdlet is a string, some of these settings can be controlled with inline options. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Inline_Path_Options for more information.

If the SeBackupPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch allows you to view and/or set security descriptors for filesystem and registry objects, even if you haven't been granted access. If you use it on any other type of object, it has no effect.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a string.

Because path resolution with the PAC module is different than PowerShell's built-in path resolution, this parameter isn't used very often. Right now, it's most common use is to access a child object where you don't have permission to view the parent object, e.g., trying to view 'c:\folder\subfolder' (a folder you have access to) when you don't have access to 'c:\folder'. In that scenario, the PAC cmdlet's path resolution would encounter an error unless LiteralPath was being used.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a string.

Ensures that the module doesn't have to detect what type of object a string path identifies. For example, a UNC path, e.g., \server\share, would be treated as a folder by default, but providing an ObjectType of 'LMShare' would cause the cmdlet to get/set the share permissions instead.
Obtains the security descriptor of the object(s) that the InputObject points to, along with any child objects. Currently works with filesystem and registry objects.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a filesystem path. When set, this switch ensures any directory paths that the string(s) resolve to are returned.
If this switch is used and the File switch is not, only directories will be returned. If both switches are used, directories and files will be returned (this is the default behavior).
To have multiple items returned by a PAC cmdlet, the string path can contain wildcards, or the New-PacSdOption can have the Recurse switch specified. See the examples for more information.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a filesystem path. When set, this switch ensures any file paths that the string(s) resolve to are returned.
If this switch is used and the Directory switch is not, only files will be returned. If both switches are used, directories and files will be returned (this is the default behavior).
To have multiple items returned by a PAC cmdlet, the string path can contain wildcards, or the New-PacSdOption can have the Recurse switch specified. See the examples for more information.
Default: $true

Allows you to control the specific sections to request when getting a security descriptor. By default, the Owner, Group, and DACL are requested. Using this parameter, any combination of the supported sections can be requested, including the Owner, Group, DACL, SACL, MIL, CAP ID.

If the SeBackupPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch allows you to view and/or set security descriptors for filesystem and registry objects, even if you haven't been granted access. If you use it on any other type of object, it has no effect.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a string.

Because path resolution with the PAC module is different than PowerShell's built-in path resolution, this parameter isn't used very often. Right now, it's most common use is to access a child object where you don't have permission to view the parent object, e.g., trying to view 'c:\folder\subfolder' (a folder you have access to) when you don't have access to 'c:\folder'. In that scenario, the PAC cmdlet's path resolution would encounter an error unless LiteralPath was being used.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a string.

Ensures that the module doesn't have to detect what type of object a string path identifies. For example, a UNC path, e.g., \server\share, would be treated as a folder by default, but providing an ObjectType of 'LMShare' would cause the cmdlet to get/set the share permissions instead.
Obtains the security descriptor of the object(s) that the InputObject points to, along with any child objects. Currently works with filesystem and registry objects.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a filesystem path. When set, this switch ensures any directory paths that the string(s) resolve to are returned.
If this switch is used and the File switch is not, only directories will be returned. If both switches are used, directories and files will be returned (this is the default behavior).
To have multiple items returned by a PAC cmdlet, the string path can contain wildcards, or the New-PacSdOption can have the Recurse switch specified. See the examples for more information.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a filesystem path. When set, this switch ensures any file paths that the string(s) resolve to are returned.
If this switch is used and the Directory switch is not, only files will be returned. If both switches are used, directories and files will be returned (this is the default behavior).
To have multiple items returned by a PAC cmdlet, the string path can contain wildcards, or the New-PacSdOption can have the Recurse switch specified. See the examples for more information.
Default: $true
If the SeSecurityPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch causes the PAC cmdlet to get a security descriptor that includes the System ACL (SACL; the list that includes audit entries).

By default, the Owner, Group, and Discretionary ACL (DACL; the list that controls who's granted/denied access) are retrieved for the object specified by InputObject. This switch will cause the SACL to also be retrieved, along with any other sections specified by other switches (like GetLabel).
This switch causes the PAC cmdlet to get a security descriptor that includes the Mandatory Integrity Level (MIL) label, if one is present.

By default, the Owner, Group, and Discretionary ACL (DACL; the list that controls who's granted/denied access) are retrieved for the object specified by InputObject. This switch will cause the MIL to also be retrieved, along with any other sections specified by other switches (like GetSacl).

If the SeBackupPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch allows you to view and/or set security descriptors for filesystem and registry objects, even if you haven't been granted access. If you use it on any other type of object, it has no effect.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a string.

Because path resolution with the PAC module is different than PowerShell's built-in path resolution, this parameter isn't used very often. Right now, it's most common use is to access a child object where you don't have permission to view the parent object, e.g., trying to view 'c:\folder\subfolder' (a folder you have access to) when you don't have access to 'c:\folder'. In that scenario, the PAC cmdlet's path resolution would encounter an error unless LiteralPath was being used.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a string.

Ensures that the module doesn't have to detect what type of object a string path identifies. For example, a UNC path, e.g., \server\share, would be treated as a folder by default, but providing an ObjectType of 'LMShare' would cause the cmdlet to get/set the share permissions instead.
Obtains the security descriptor of the object(s) that the InputObject points to, along with any child objects. Currently works with filesystem and registry objects.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a filesystem path. When set, this switch ensures any directory paths that the string(s) resolve to are returned.
If this switch is used and the File switch is not, only directories will be returned. If both switches are used, directories and files will be returned (this is the default behavior).
To have multiple items returned by a PAC cmdlet, the string path can contain wildcards, or the New-PacSdOption can have the Recurse switch specified. See the examples for more information.
This is only used when a PAC cmdlet's InputObject parameter is a filesystem path. When set, this switch ensures any file paths that the string(s) resolve to are returned.
If this switch is used and the Directory switch is not, only files will be returned. If both switches are used, directories and files will be returned (this is the default behavior).
To have multiple items returned by a PAC cmdlet, the string path can contain wildcards, or the New-PacSdOption can have the Recurse switch specified. See the examples for more information.
Default: $true

Allows you to control the specific sections to request when getting a security descriptor. By default, the Owner, Group, and DACL are requested. Using this parameter, any combination of the supported sections can be requested, including the Owner, Group, DACL, SACL, MIL, CAP ID.
If the SeSecurityPrivilege privilege has been granted, this switch causes the PAC cmdlet to get a security descriptor that includes the System ACL (SACL; the list that includes audit entries).

By default, the Owner, Group, and Discretionary ACL (DACL; the list that controls who's granted/denied access) are retrieved for the object specified by InputObject. This switch will cause the SACL to also be retrieved, along with any other sections specified by other switches (like GetLabel).
This switch causes the PAC cmdlet to get a security descriptor that includes the Mandatory Integrity Level (MIL) label, if one is present.

By default, the Owner, Group, and Discretionary ACL (DACL; the list that controls who's granted/denied access) are retrieved for the object specified by InputObject. This switch will cause the MIL to also be retrieved, along with any other sections specified by other switches (like GetSacl).
This command does not take any pipeline input

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will return the effective access for the 'C:\folder' folder, and any child objects that the user running the script has access to. If an object that the running user has no access to is encountered, an error will be written and cmdlet execution will resume. The following modification could be made so that objects that the running user doesn't have access to could still be processed (on a normal machine, this would require the user to be an administrator): PS> Get-PacEffectiveAccess C:\folder -Principal UserName -PacSDOption (New-PacSdOption -Recurse -BypassAclCheck)
This will return any access control entries from the DACL (which would have happened by default), and the SACL (which happens because the Audit switch is passed to New-PacSDOption)

Without this PacSDOption, the NTFS permissions for the \server\share location would have been obtained. Because a PacSDOption with the 'LMShare' ObjectType was provided, the share permissions are obtained instead.

maml:description.maml:para:
Causes the modified security descriptor to be saved. By default, when a security descriptor object is provided as input to the InputObject parameter, the in memory security descriptor is changed, and a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor saves the changes. Using the Apply switch causes the change to be made without a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor.
If a non security descriptor object is provided as input and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
When the -Apply switch is used, or when a non-security descriptor object is passed as input, this switch parameter suppresses any prompts about saving the changes to the security descriptor.

A securable object whose ACL will be changed. This can either be an instance of an object, e.g., output from Get-CimInstance, Get-ChildItem, Get-Item, etc, or a string pointing to the location of the securable object. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module for more information.
.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
Shows what would happen if the function were to make changes. No changes are made when this switch is used.
Prompts you for confirmation before making any changes.

If a non security descriptor object is provided as input and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.

This cmdlet takes several types of objects as input, including objects output from Get-Item, Get-ChildItem, Get-WmiObject, Get-CimInstance, Get-Acl, and simple strings.
The command only writes output if the PassThru parameter was provided.
Changes the owner of a securable object.
Set-PacOwner allows the changing of a securable object's owner. An administrator can take ownership or assign ownership to another user or group (as long as they have the proper privileges).
A regular user can take ownership of an object in certain circumstances (specifically if they have the WRITE_DAC, a.k.a. TakeOwnership, access right assigned in an object's DACL).

By default, if a security descriptor object obtained from Get-Acl or Get-PacSecurityDescriptor is passed as input, the cmdlet changes the in memory security descriptor without committing the changes (this behavior can be changed by using the Apply switch).

If a supported object is passed that isn't a security descriptor, the cmdlet changes the security descriptor and attempts to commit the change (this behavior can be changed by using the PassThru switch).
The new owner of the object. This can be a string representing a user, group, or computer object. It can also be a SecurityIdentifier instance.

Causes the modified owner information to be saved. By default, when a security descriptor object is provided as input to the InputObject parameter, the in memory security descriptor is changed, and a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor saves the changes. Using the Apply switch causes the change to be made without a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor.
If a non security descriptor object is provided as input, and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
When the -Apply switch is used, or when a non-security descriptor object is passed as input, this switch parameter suppresses any prompts about saving the changes to the security descriptor.

A securable object whose owner will be changed. This can either be an instance of an object, e.g., output from Get-CimInstance, Get-ChildItem, Get-Item, etc, or a string pointing to the location of the securable object. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module for more information.
.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
Shows what would happen if the function were to make changes. No changes are made when this switch is used.
Prompts you for confirmation before making any changes.
The new owner of the object. This can be a string representing a user, group, or computer object. It can also be a SecurityIdentifier instance.

Causes the modified owner information to be saved. By default, when a security descriptor object is provided as input to the InputObject parameter, the in memory security descriptor is changed, and a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor saves the changes. Using the Apply switch causes the change to be made without a separate call to Set-PacSecurityDescriptor.
If a non security descriptor object is provided as input, and the PassThru switch is not specified, the default behavior is to set this switch and prompt the user before saving the security descriptor.
Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
When the -Apply switch is used, or when a non-security descriptor object is passed as input, this switch parameter suppresses any prompts about saving the changes to the security descriptor.

A securable object whose owner will be changed. This can either be an instance of an object, e.g., output from Get-CimInstance, Get-ChildItem, Get-Item, etc, or a string pointing to the location of the securable object. See about_PowerShellAccessControl_Module for more information.
.NET security descriptors (obtained through Get-Acl or the GetAccessControl() method that's present on some objects) can also be used as the input object.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
Shows what would happen if the function were to make changes. No changes are made when this switch is used.
Prompts you for confirmation before making any changes.
This cmdlet takes several types of objects as input, including objects output from Get-Item, Get-ChildItem, Get-WmiObject, Get-CimInstance, Get-Acl, and simple strings.
The command only writes output if the PassThru parameter was provided.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will set the owner of the 'C:\FolderYouCantView' folder to the current user. This is the same as taking ownership. This command should work even if you can't view the security descriptor of the object (assuming you have been granted the SeTakeOwnerhipPrivilege privilege and/or the SeRestorePrivilege).

Since the InputObject is not a security descriptor, the command will get the security descriptor for the folder, make the change to the owner, and attempt to save the change. You will be prompted before the change is permanently saved. You can suppress the prompt with the Force switch.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS> $RegKey = "HKCU:\Software\KeyYouCantAccess" PS> $OriginalOwner = Get-PacSecurityDescriptor $RegKey -PacSDOption (New-PacSDOption -BypassAclCheck -SecurityDescriptorSections Owner) | % Owner Get-PacSecurityDescriptor $RegKey -PacSDOption (New-PacSDOption -BypassAclCheck) | Set-PacOwner -PassThru -Apply -Force | Add-PacAccessControlEntry -Principal Everyone -RegistryRights ReadKey -PassThru | Set-PacOwner -Principal $OriginalOwner -Apply -Force

maml:description.maml:para: Causes the modified security descriptor object to be written to the pipeline. By default, this function does not generate any output.
Suppresses the prompt before the security descriptor is saved.
Advanced command options. For more information, see the New-PacSDOption help.
Shows what would happen if the function were to make changes. No changes are made when this switch is used.
Prompts you for confirmation before making any changes.
